page.title: 16ST JAMES' SELHAM
page.content: {" Isn't it tiny? " "We could fit it in {our classroom." }Selham Church is a beauty,a model of Saxon architecture, nave and chancel only,tall and narrow, thin 11th century walls and tiny windows. One capital of the chancel arch has serpents eating their own tails - a Viking symbol of eternity. Dense blues and reds of the shields in the glass link us with the first Domesday.{"EGBERT KING OF ENGLAND, {WILLIAM DUKE OF NORMANDY,TAILLEFER {COUNT OF ANGOULEME,THE KINGDOM OF {FRANCE AND CASTILLE,THE DUKEDOM OF {BURGUNDY,& THE FAMILIES OF PLANTAGENET {SCOPE,FITZALAN,AND BELLASIS."}The shields commemorate the lineage of the children of Rector Robert Blackburn who gave the Victorian glass which tells the story of our salvation. We found spaces for 37 people. {It really is a peaceful place.
